body: it's libwayland limitation, nothing alacritty can do about other than shrink the title for you.
I'm not closing this issue to track title shrinking. One more thing is flood with title events, that could also crash or deadlock, due to libwayland again.

rename.from: Long window title causes panic "Argument list too long"
rename.to: Limit the maximum length of the title

body: Generally I wouldn't be opposed to just limit it on all platforms. I think that would probably be the easiest solution. Generally an implementation in winit might make sense?

>Generally an implementation in winit might make sense?

it's not true on all platforms, and so I've proposed such change in sctk https://github.com/Smithay/client-toolkit/issues/110. So we can avoid limiting very long titles.

However I do belive that there's no value in very long titles, since you won't see them any way. And that's the thing I've suggested in the past to limit them to 1024 chars in alacritty_terminal, when managing the title stack, though the idea was rejected. But I was coming from the exact same crash, and so we have an issue in sctk due to that.

There're other ways to crash due to libwayland-client though, like spamming with title udpates.

> I've suggested in the past to limit them to 1024 chars in alacritty_terminal

Yeah, I still don't think that's the right choice. Either SCTK or winit should be better. I agree that having titles longer than 1024 probably doesn't make a ton of sense on any platform.
Hello I would like to contribute a solution. When you say winit, are you referring to alacritty/src/window.rs?

We mean https://github.com/rust-windowing/winit . But I don't really like to put it in winit on all platforms, I'd rather put it somewhere else, on a platforms where it breaks things, like Wayland, and so added it to either it directly or smithay-client-toolkit library, which it's using.

I've assigned myself, since the original issue is fixed upstream and title is limited right now on Wayland. if we want to do something like that in alacritty as well. Let me know, since I don't really see a reason for it.
